keyTakeAways: ICE arrested Radule Bojovic, a police officer in Hanover Park, Illinois, accusing him of overstaying a tourist visa that expired in 2015.
Bojovic is from Montenegro and was allegedly living in the U.S. illegally for 10 years, which the Department of Homeland Security claims violates federal immigration law.
The Hanover Park Police Department previously reported that Bojovic had completed field training and was preparing for full duty, indicating a prior belief in his legal status.
Local officials, including Mayor Rodney Craig, stated that hiring procedures included thorough background checks and that Bojovic was legally authorized to work at the time of hiring.
Federal officials, including DHS Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin, criticized the hiring of a person living illegally, calling it a violation of U.S. law and a breach of public trust.
This case is part of a broader pattern of ICE enforcement actions, including the earlier arrest of an Iowa school superintendent for similar immigration violations.
The incident has sparked public debate about immigration enforcement, police hiring standards, and the balance between national security and civil liberties.

summaryOfNewsArticle: ICE arrested Radule Bojovic, a police officer in Hanover Park, Illinois, accusing him of overstaying a tourist visa from Montenegro that expired in 2015, having lived illegally in the U.S. for 10 years. The Department of Homeland Security claims he violated federal immigration laws, including firearm possession, while the local government maintains that thorough hiring procedures—including FBI and Illinois State Police background checks—ensured he was legally authorized to work at the time of employment. The incident has sparked public debate about police hiring standards, immigration enforcement, and the integrity of public safety institutions. This case is part of a broader pattern of federal immigration enforcement, including a similar arrest of an Iowa school superintendent in September 2025.
